comments.commentBody:
Haven't we been hearing for the last several months that the job situation has been looking up? Personally, I believe the 117,000 jobs
created last month consist mainly of individuals hired to paste those little labels on every piece of fruit and vegetable in the supermarkets. Thank God they haven't got round to the $.50 ears of corn yet! Now those are going to be really tough to remove.
I agree with Dale. Steve, you really would do other readers a service by being more selective and/or posting on your own blog and offering links here.

#'s 3,4,6,7,8,9,15,16,17,18,19,20,23,24,25,26,27,29,30,31,34,35,36,37,38,39,40,41,42 and 43

Steven Earl Salmony, Chapel Hill, NC

Dear Mr. Salmony,

J'Accuse!!!

I accuse you of recycling old posts.

I recognize your #43 from over a year ago. That "What is Galileo doing tonight?" line rang my funny bone then. You may recall we traded barbs about it back then, when I was so ungracious as to point out that Galileo is not doing anything tonight because he's been dead since 1642.

Unlike red wine, that line has not improved with age.

J'Accuse!!!

I accuse you of abusing our host Andy's generous policy of posting everything that comes his way. Out of 43 messages in this thread, some 30 of them are yours. You have flooded Dot Earth with over 900 lines of composition, by my estimate something like 8000 words.

Had you composed all this verbiage yourself, today, it would have been an awe-inspiring feat.

But you didn't compose all this today, did you, Mr. Salmony? I cannot rid myself of a suspicion that you dumped a couple dozen old messages you had lurking on your hard drive onto Dot Earth.

J'Accuse!!!

I accuse you of boring your fellow Dot Earth patrons to death with this verbal Niagara.

May I make a suggestion?

Reduce your arguments in the 30 posts, 900 lines and 8000 words above to an "elevator speech".

Imagine that you get on an elevator on the ground floor of the United Nations. On this elevator are Barak Obama, Hillary Clinton, the Premier of China and the Prime Minister of India. They are all going to get off on the fifth floor, but they cannot avoid your message before then.

What would you tell them?

Reduce all your passion, your concern and your belief to something shorter than the Gettysburg Address, something you could speak clearly and convincingly as the elevator rises from the ground floor to the fifth floor in less than, say, two minutes.

I promise you, this will be much more effective than 30 posts of 8000 inedible words.
I agree with Dale. Steve, you really would do other readers a service by being more selective and/or posting on your own blog and offering links here.

As I approach my 75th birthday this month, I am totally depressed. My father came to the US as a 12 year old from Scotland and started in the WV coal mines. He made it possible for me to go to college and I began a career as a weather officer in the US Air Force. The Air Force sent me to NYU for a year and 3 years later to MIT for two years where I received masters degrees in Meteorology and Aero-Astro. I know something about infrared heat transfer in the atmosphere. If the earth's atmosphere were 100% N2 and O2, without greenhouse gases, the earth would be 21C (37F) cooler. Add more greenhouse gases and we get even more warmer.

I am a retired Air Force colonel weather officer who was educated in meteorology at NYU and MIT and I know quite a bit about greenhouse gases and infrared heat transfer in the atmosphere. Man-made global warming is real and it is a serious problem.

It is probably already too late to do anything about it. The good news is that the most destructive species the earth has known, homo sapiens, is on its way to extinction. Without human intervention, planet earth will find its way to a pleasant equilibrium. Perhaps a new species will emerge with intelligence, but without the intellectual-destructive force known as religion.

We deny the proven science of evolution and global warming, but accept the garbage of the rapture and supernatural fairy tales.

We truly deserve our fate.

Please, carefully examine and crunch the numbers, as Terry McNeil (#44) is suggesting. The numbers derived from science are to be valued more than whatever numbers come to us from preternatural ideology, however attractive and self-serving the ideology may be.

If we simply stop to see the numbers from science for what they disclose to us about the world we inhabit, it does not take a rocket scientist to understand that we are witnessing the explosion of a dangerous and ultimately destructive population bomb, not a benign bulge of human population numbers on a road to automatic population stabilization and a natural end to population growth on Earth a mere four decades from now.

Look at the hundreds of thousands of years it took for the human population on Earth to grow to 1 billion. Now compare that time frame with the one which presents the increase of absolute global human population numbers from the 1 billion mark to 7 billion in 2011. What do you see? How do you account for the skyrocketing increase in human population numbers in such a short period of time? Did an increasing supply of food for human consumption cause the increase of human population numbers because the best available, unchallenged scientific evidence indicates with remarkable clarity and simplicity that human population numbers are a function of food supply; that the greater the food supply, the greater the numbers of a species? The population dynamics of the human species is essentially similar to the population dynamics of other species.

SE Compact QR5 wind turbine by Britain’s “quiet revolution llc” to make wind power in urban environments. (the urban turbine)

Skimore, Owings + Merrill (SOM) built world’s first skyscraper with built-in wind turbines at 23rd and 46th floors--but they built it in China! (Pearl River Tower). Why don’t we build things like that in America? Would it make too much sense?

Who in the world are all these coal/oil industry spammers and ideologues that target Revkin's science reporting in the NYT?  Couldn't the fossil fuel industry find a better way to invest its billions in profits this year; say, by employing unemployed Americans in energy efficiency?  I realize it is a religious, anti-science perspective that fuels these spammers, but they really should try to have more concern for their fellow citizens in a changing climate.

“69% Say It’s Likely Scientists Have Falsified Global Warming Research”

One reason that poll is skewed is because I, ( I’m sure you would label me an alarmist) would answer yes to that question but not because of anything to do with “Climategate”.

Do the names Pat Michaels, Roy Spencer, John Christy, Timothy Ball et al ring any bells.
Wow, could heat in the comments about this article be a posable contributor global warming?
S&P, GOP (the Get Obama Party), Grover Norquist and Americans for Prosperity - Bin Laden sends his thanks from the grave.

We are hollowing out our manufacturing base by buying ever more goods from overseas on borrowed money, a perpetual trade deficit. Our federal government runs endless fiscal deficits with no plans on the table to stop them, ever. Our banking system and entire economy are still weak and nearly collapsed due to a giant mortgage scam it created with the help of members of congress and their "fair housing" acts, with Fannie and Freddie the giant government directed enablers, with a Federal Reserve that held interest rates way too low for way too long, w no real oversight by congress or by corrupt, government anointed ratings agencies.

Added to this is an over-indebted and dare I say overindulged citizenry which has no problem buying more foreign goods than our country can afford, demanding more transfer payments and health care than government can afford and taking out mortgages that many of them knew full well that they personally couldn't afford.

And you people are surprised that we might not be the best credit risk in the world?

What a joke from a bunch of clowns. S&P has threatened this before, but really, they have no credibility whatsoever, and are simply trying to assert some.

It's also a baldfaced attempt to effect policy towards further debt reduction, by the same richest of the rich who run the country as it is. The more noise they can make to distract everyone while the richest line their own pockets as everyone else gets poorer, and put more controls in place to make sure more and more people will remain uneducated and underemployed... What a farce.
In so many ways, we're becoming like a less-developed country.
“Judgment flawed by a $14 trillion deficit speaks for itself,”

It may be time to nationalize the financial sector. We should not give the power to destroy global or national economies to single corporate citizens. Such power seemingly makes them the new nobility, blessed with more authority and power than the rest of us. Such an entity cannot be allowed to exist

What people don't understand is that rich have to make money. Now US government has to pay higher interest rate on money it borrows. Who do you think will benefit from higher interest?  Didn't I just  read how luxury items were flying of the shelves.
If their decision is based on Congress's ability to operate, I agree with their decision.

S&P?  Would that be the same S&P that rated the high risk mortgaged back securities as better than cash?  Give me a break.  The President should call these incompetent Wall Street stooges out for what they really are, snake oil salesmen who sell triple A ratings to the highest bidder.
Just tax Harry #41.  Don't raise my taxes.  He can pay what I still owe for last year, as I sure as sheep-lips, don't have the money.
Now that US debt has been downgraded does that prevent the Social Security Administration from loaning to a now less than perfect borrower?

Many readers seem to be in denial about the state of the US economy and its sovereign debt. For too long the US has paid for excessive defence spending that it couldnt afford by borrowing from China, Japan, and Russia,yes Russia, and if that wasnt enough it just printed new money. At the same time US tax rates are only two thirds of the OECD average. The AA rating is too high! China's Dagong agency which is recognised around the world as being more accurate and reliable than the three US ratings agencies, has just lowered the USA to a single A with negative outlook! However Dagong still rates about ten countries including Norway, Sweden, Finland, Switzerland, Australia and New Zealand at AAA.

Our congratulations to the T Party gang, in creating a "public squabble" over this nation's budget, and so shaking confidence that "Sound as a dollar" is no longer valid. With S&P's downgrade, will come others. Foreign investors will send money to other nations. Our inflation rate, interest rates will increase, costing millions of Americans billions of dollars. The value of the dollar will continue to decline. Yes, T-Party heroes, you can now brag that you have cost Americans more billions than you ever could have saved in your petty budget squabble.

In many nations, a group that hurt their nation would be considered traitors. In this nation, a T-Party radical, can use the name of God, hold a Bible and call himself a patriot in front of a flag, while he does more damage to the USA than any group has in 40 years.

Let American voters understand, you put these people in office. Surely you can see your mistake and the cost.
As for us, we withdraw from the stock market, and we fear for our banking system. It would seem that the T-Party and the Republicans that they intimidate, have extended the recession by years. Congrats airheads.

I think if a business analyst were to evaluate the U.S. government, its income and expenses, and its inability to make good management decisions, the U.S. would be fortunate to get a C rating.  It would also be rated 'moderate to high risk'.
I think that this is clearly the case of the tail wagging the dog.

Standard & Poors gave the CDOs of the sub-prime mortgage sercuriies a AAA rating until just about the day the finical crisis began. You can't say that the US Government is less likely to pay back it's debt then those who defaulted on their mortgages in 2008. These companies have second agendas always. None the less Congress needs to get a grip and start to compromise.
